text: A large sign on the entrance wall reads: "MASON MARINE BO SALES." Underneath, another sign reads: "GIGANTIC BLOWOUT

A dozen 17-25 foot powerboats are evenly spaced in a neat line -- family boats, fishing boats, small cabin cruisers and ski boats. The boats are all spotless and shine in th afternoon sun. The boats are marked with balloons and sig

head_text.subj: "ON SALE," "THIS WEEKEND ONLY," "ONE OF A KIND."

text: A large whiteboard displays monthly sales figures. "C.J." has sold more than the other three salesmen combined. C.J. MASON writes on the whiteboard. Three salesmen sit a a table watching him. C.J. is the owner of Mason Marine. He's around 40, fit, white smile. Behind C.J. are several black and white pictures of he an his father fishing - one picture when C.J. is a young boy holding a toy TUG BOAT, one picture where C.J. is a teena and one more recent picture. Meet FRANK, 50ish, bearded, wearing a Hawaiian shirt, and stuffing a bear claw in his mouth; STEVE, looks like Neil Diamond in a shirt and tie; and KYLE, early 20's, spiked, frosted hair. C.J. You've got to create urgency with the customer. C.J. talks with a lot of intensity. He writes "Create Urgency" on the whiteboard and underlines it three times.
Kyle and a customer, DEAN, walk around a 19-foot fishing
You've got time. This thing's been here for like six months. C.J. steps up next to Kyle.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Actually, I have someone coming in this afternoon to put a deposit on this boat. We've got some other ones if you want to look at those?
No, I kind of like this one. C.J. Well, my customer is coming at two, so if you decide you want it, let me know before then. Dean looks at his watch.
C.J. writes "Begin Negotiation" on the whiteboard. C.J. Every customer is a buyer, no matter what they say. Buyers are liars. You just have to decide on a price.
Steve and ADAM look at a 20-foot ski boat.
This big bad boat is twelve thousand nine hundered and ninty-nine dollars. Do you want to pay with cash or credit card?
I really can't afford that much. Adam turns to leave. C.J. steps in. C.J. Suppose I could sell you this boat for a dollar? Would you take it right now? Adam turns back and looks at C.J. and Steve.
Yeah, let's hook it up to my truck. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  3*.
Steve, C.J. and Adam look at the boat, which is now hooke to Adam's truck. C.J. Looks good, doesn't it?
It sure does. C.J. Now of course I can't sell it to you for a dollar. But what price did you have in mind?

I was looking to spend around ten thousand dollars. C.J. What if I could make it happen for two fifty a month, would you take this boat home today? Adam rings his hands together nervously and thinks for a moment. C.J. What about two forty a month?

C.J. writes "Follow Through" on the whiteboard and underl it four times. C.J. Follow through is everything in sales. If you're not going to follow through, you might as well not even be here. Frank takes a bite of his bear claw and NODS, clearly off space.
Frank and PATRICK look at a 17' bass boat.
I have to talk to my wife.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  3A*.

Okay, great. I'll be here all week. Give me a call and let me know what she says. Frank turns and starts walking away. C.J. moves up next t Frank and turns him back around towards Patrick. C.J. Is your wife home now? Let's drive over and show it to her.

I think it would be better if I talked to her first. C.J. Okay. Let me get your phone number. I've got someone coming to look at the boat this afternoon. If they don't buy it, I'll give you a call. Patrick NODS. C.J. How late are you up?
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11 12 13 14 4a,
C.J. drives on the freeway, talking into a cell phone hea C.J. What did your wife say? (and) I'm sorry to hear that. Is she there now? (and) Could I talk to her?

C.J. continues to talk into his headset. He puts the gas nozzle into his tank and gets back into his truck, still talking. C.J. Yeah, I understand. I've been there myself. You have to remember, you're buying more than a boat. You're buying memories for your family. (and) Some of my best childhood memories are being out with my dad on our 1956 Bell Boy.

EXT. C.d.'S HOUSE - DRIVEWAY - NIGHT 14 C.J. gets out of his truck, still talking into the headse C.J. (into phone) I'll even throw in a Wave Raider tube to pull the kids behind the boat with. They'll love it. C.J. sees the gas nozzle dangling from his car. Without missing a beat, he pulls it out and drops it into the tra can. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

C.J. and his family eat dinner. C.J. continues to talk on the phone. His family consists of his two sons, TOMMY (age 8), TYLER (age 6), and his wife, MADELINE (age 35), who's pregnant. The house is quite small, and the dining room area is mer an extension of the living room. C.J. (into phone) Sometimes me and my wife take the boat out for a romantic weekend without the kids.
(sotto) You must mean your other wife.
Why is daddy on the phone so much?
He's a hyperactive, neurotic, pathological salesman. C.J. motions for them to be quiet.

The bedroom is tiny. C.J. and Madeline lie in bed. C.J. continues to talk on the phone. Madeline picks up her cel phone and dials -- C.J. doesn't notice. C.J. Congratulations. You're going to be so happy with this boat. (and) Could you hold on a second? I have a call on the other line. (and) Hello?
(into phone) It's time for bed!
Steve, Frank, and Kyle stare at C.J. as he finishes his s
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
I was on the phone with his wife for four hours. I got a brain tumor, but I made the sale. Steve starts clapping. Kyle and Frank join in with him, although Frank's effort is half-hearted at best.
You're amazing, just amazing. That's a great sale, man. C.J. So let's make this our best month ever. Anyone who pulls a hat trick gets a two hundred and fifty dollar cash bonus.
Steve talks to a young hip customer, BILL.

This is a great boat. I can just see you cruising through the harbor in this thing, everyone looking at you, all the chicks asking you for a ride. I could go out with you and be your wingman. The Stevester and Bill out on the water.
Oh, yeah, sure. Listen I have to run. I have to meet my fiancee for dinner.
Oh, a romantic dinner? So you're setting her up for a little bit of the old in and out? Steve PUMPS his hips back and forth.
Frank talks to a MIDDLE-AGED CUSTOMER.
You're going to need a boat. Unless the government does something about global warming, this whole place is going to be underwater. Forget Jesus, Al Gore is the only one who can save us now.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19 20 21
19 The middle aged customer looks at Frank and NODS politely
Kyle talks to an OLDER CUSTOMER.
Dude, do you want it or not? This thing is tight.

20 21 A badminton net is set up in the middle of the huge backy C.J. and Tyler are on one side of the net and Tommy and K HOFFERMAN are on the other side. Kevin is Madeline's fath He's around sixty-five and in great shape, with a tattoo an eagle on his forearm. Tommy whacks the shuttlecock over to the other side of th net and it hits the ground.

Nice shot, Tommy! You're not like your father. You're a winner! C.J. Don't listen to your grandfather, Tommy. He's an insecure, egomaniac who resents me because I have a career that I'm passionate about.

He's right, Tommy. I wish I'd barely gotten by selling used boats instead of fighting for our freedom and then having a very successful career in banking and vacationing in Europe. Not to mention a real house to raise my family in. C.J. Aren't you late for your next cocktail? Mr. Hofferman serves the shuttlecock hard and it hits C.J the chest. Ouch!
Victory!
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Mr. Hofferman gives Tommy a high-five.
Down for twenty. Mr. Hofferman and Tommy drop to the ground and start doin push-ups.
Tyler, come over here. You're a winner, too. You just ended up on the wrong team. Tyler runs over to Tommy and Mr. Hofferman and starts doi push-ups. Mr. Hofferman jumps up from doing his push-ups.
Hooah!
Hooah! Madeline and MRS. HOFFERMAN exit the house. Mrs. Hofferma carries a cocktail and hands it to Mr. Hofferman.
There's an open house across the street. Since you're so successful selling used boats, why don't we go take a look at it. C.J. That sounds like a fantastic idea.
Great. Let's go. As Mr. Hofferman turns away, C.J. scratches his forehead his middle finger.
C.J., Madeline, Tommy, Tyler, and Mr. and Mrs. Hofferman across the street. Mr. Hofferman carries ten pound dumbbells and does reps a chants:
I don't know, but I've been told.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
I don't know, but I've been told.
Selling boats is for assholes.
Selling boats is for assholes.
Dad!
The house is gorgeous. A lush green lawn leads up to two pillars on either side of a large, dark wooden door.

C.J., Madeline, Tommy, Tyler, and Mr. and Mrs. Hofferman enter. A huge chandelier hangs down from the second story. A lar staircase leads up. The house is elegant and enormous. JOHNNY CROSS (age 35), the realtor, tall and handsome, strides towards them oozing used car salesman charm.
How are you folks today?
Fine, thank you. We live across the street, but wanted to bring our daughter and son-in-law over to see the place.
They really can't afford it. He sells used boats.
Actually, you might be surprised. There are some very creative loan options out there.
You'd have to be Michelangelo to create that loan. C.J. I sell a lot of boats, and we have considerable equity in our house.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24 25 10.
I'm sure we can work something out. Obstacles are meant to be overcome. Mr. Hofferman rolls his eyes as he continues to do reps w the dumbbells.

Johnny, C.J., Mr. and Mrs. Hofferman, Madeline, Tyler, an Tommy enter. The living room is every bit as elegant as t rest of the house, with a huge sprawling kitchen on one s and a great living area on the other. Two french doors le out to a huge backyard.
What ungodly amount of money are they asking?
Seven and a quarter. The phone hasn't stopped ringing since they listed it. I'm tempted to buy it myself and flip it. Johnny pulls a mini-football out of his briefcase.
Hey, kids. Why don't you go outside and throw the football around. It's a great backyard.
Yeah! Johnny tosses the football to Tommy as they run outside.
I'll keep an eye on them. Mrs. Hofferman goes out after them.
If you married Blake Frasier, you'd be living here now.
Blake used to wear dresses and loved musicals.
That's absurd. He was a marine.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
25 C.J. Come on, Kevin. Like you never soaped up with your platoon mates.
You watch your tongue!
Enough!
What is your current payment? C.J. Around eighteen hundred per month.
So if I could get you into this house for around the same amount, you'd put in an offer today? C.J. Yeah, I guess.
How much equity do you have in your house? C.J. About a hundred thousand. Johnny whips out a calculator and starts inputting number

If you could put down one-fifty, and placed an offer of seven hundred, and took a fifty year mortgage, your payment would only be around twenty- four hundred. That's pretty close to your current payment.
Not really. C.J. A fifty year mortgage? I'm forty-one years old.
I'm sorry, but we can't afford this place.
Why don't you guys put in an offer for seven hundred. (more)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.

26 JOHNNY (cont'd) It probably won't even be accepted. And even if it is, you can always back out during escrow. (a beat) It really would be perfect for your family. C.J. looks out the window at Tommy and Tyler throwing the football around the huge backyard.

You're wasting your time. Mickey Mouse has bigger balls than he does. Madeline gives her father a look. He looks away and start doing reps again. C.J. rings his hands together nervously. A long beat, and then -- C.J. (with renewed confidence) Let's put in the offer.
C.J. and Madeline enter. Madeline starts quickly undressi She's pissed. C.J. We've always wanted to live ina house like that.
How are we going to afford an extra six hundred dollars a month? C.J. Don't worry. It's going to be okay.
Did you think about the property taxes? The taxes are going to be three times what they are on this place. C.J. Just trust me on this. I got it.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

And how in the world are we going to come up with a hundred and fifty thousand dollars? We're lucky if we have eighty-five in this place. C.J. I'm going to be making some major changes down at the shop.
What are you going to do? C.J. I'm going to hire some new guys who are really motivated to sell. And if the old guys don't step up, I'm going to let them go.

You've been saying that for five years. You're too nice. You're never going to let them go. C.J. Once I get some better sales guys, I'm going to make them commission only. It'll starve the beast. They'll either sell or they won't make any money. Madeline pulls off her earrings and sets them on the coun C.J. Let me do this for our family. C.J. moves up behind Madeline. C.J. We can't let fear run our lives.
Okay, mister infomercial, I'm not letting fear run my life. I'm letting reality run my life. Madeline rolls her eyes and walks into the bathroom.
The deck is roped off like a dock and has several pieces patio furniture on it, including a table and chairs.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14.

Frank eats a doughnut. Steve sits at the table drinking D Coke. Kyle sits next to them writing in his notebook and DRUMMING out beats on the table. Steve lights a cigarette and offers one to Kyle, who acce it. Frank fans the smoke away, annoyed.
He may sell twice as many boats as I do, but I have balance in my life. Do you know what I was doing last night while he was selling boats?
Petting the one-eyed snake?
No, asshole. I was coaching my daughter's soccer team in the regional quarterfinals.
Same difference. Kyle continues drumming on the table.
(to Kyle) What are you doing?
I'm writing a new song, man.
All the great rock was written in the seventies. You should write a song like Stairway To Heaven. Led Zeppelin was the greatest band of all time.
You're high, dude. We're way better than Led Zeppelin. You should see my guitar player. He's a lot better than that guy... what's his name?
Jimmy Page? Your guitar player is better than Jimmy Page?
Yeah, a lot better.
What's his name, Eddie Van Hendrix?
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
No, his name is Mike.
Forget it. Kyle goes back to writing in his notebook.
HARVEY enters. He's a bit eccentric, wearing an old windbreaker patched with duct tape and glasses that are a large for his balding head.
Frank shoots Steve a look and Steve winks at him.
Kyle, since you're the new guy, why don't you take this one.
That guy? He looks homeless.
The ones who look like that have all the money.
I'll take him, but when I sell him that Four Winns cabin cruiser, don't come crying to me. Steve stands up. Kyle glances at him and then stands up.
I got it. Kyle moves out toward Harvey.
Kyle holds out his hand to Harvey.
Welcome to Mason Marine. I'm Kyle. Harvey gives him a once over.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15A*.
I just bought three boats at a charity auction. Got a great deal. Two hundred fifty bucks for all three.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29 30 31 32 33
29 Kyle turns his head and shoots Steve and Frank a really m glance.
Steve and Frank bust up LAUGHING.
I buried two of the boats in the ground and made septic tanks out of them.
Septic tanks?
Yeah, I just put some old plywood over them and ran the plumbing to my trailer.
Are you serious?
Yeah, it works great. The third boat runs pretty well, and I want to take it to Mexico. 30 31 Kyle just NODS his head as Harvey continues to RAMBLE on.
Steve stands talking to a young couple, beside a ski boat. DAN and DEBBIE, In the background, Kyle still talks to Harvey.

I'm envious. You guys are going to have a great summer! Let's go in and finish up the paperwork. You'll have to take the Stevester skiing sometime. Steve extends his hand to both of them and they shake.
C.J. stands at the counter talking to Kyle. 32 33
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17.
You're helping Harvey?
You know that guy? C.J. He comes in here all the time. If you want to be successful in sales, you have to know the difference between light and heat.
He's cool. I won't spend too much more time with him. Kyle exits. Steve enters carrying a stack of papers.
I just sold that Larson out there. Made a great deal on it. C.J. Did you up sell any accessories?
Nah, they could barely afford the boat. C.J. Finance the accessories.
Yeah, I'll talk to them about that as an option. Frank's sits at the counter. He looks up at Steve and C.J and notices Dan and Debbie standing outside.
Did you just sell to that couple?
Yeah, why?
That's my be-back. I talked to them last week!
Yeah, right, prove it. Frank pulls out a small pad and starts flipping through i
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18.
(to Steve, pointing at his pad) Here, right here, Dan and Debbie! Steve rolls his eyes.
You're the "half deal" king because you can't close anything yourself. This is my deal.
(to C.J.) C'mon C.J., you know this is half my deal. Frank shows C.J. his pad of paper. C.J. Steve, it does look like he talked to them last week.

C'mon C.J., quit standing on my dick! Whoever closes the deal should get the money. I'm just going to start taking down names and taking half deals. That'd be a hell of a lot easier than closing them. C.J. You know the rules.
(to Frank) Then you go out there and up sell the accessories. C.J. Yeah, that's a good idea.

Forget it. You can have it. C.J. What? Where is your motivation? I'll go out there and sell them the accessories myself! C.J. angrily snatches the paperwork out of Steve's hand a walks out the door. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19.

C.J., Frank and Steve wave as Dan and Debbie drive away i their SUV towing the boat. The SUV is packed with accessories, literally falling out windows -- life jackets, rubber bumpers, anchors, ropes, fire extinguisher, a boat cover, water skis, a wake board and a huge inflatable yellow hotdog wave rider strapped t the roof. C.J. You know what guys? I've had it! You guys are -- MUSIC blares as Johnny pulls up in his Corvette. C.J. tur and sees Johnny Cross.
Hey, Captain, so this is your lot? Johnny steps forward and holds out his hand to Frank and Steve.
Johnny Cross. A pleasure to meet you. They shake hands. C.J. Have you heard anything on my offer?
It's being handled by another agent in the office. I'm getting out of real estate. C.J. Really?

That's actually why I came by. (beat) I've sold all kinds of stuff from lemonade when I was a kid to cars to real estate, and I've always been the best. And while I love to sell, I've never loved what I was selling. Frank rolls his eyes.
When I was a kid, my grandfather used to take me fishing. (more)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20.

JOHNNY (cont'd) We'd leave early in the morning when the lake was like glass. I used to love watching the wake from the motor behind the boat. To this day, the smell of gasoline and two-stroke oil brings me right back there. So when you and I met, it was like I got slapped in the face. Why not sell boats? I brought my work history with some references. Johnny hands C.J. his RESUME. C.J. glances at it.
We don't need another salesman. C.J. Actually, we do. We're headed into the busy season. (to Johnny) But you really have to know boats to be able to sell them.
I learn quickly. Give me a shot. You won't be sorry. C.J. hesitates.
I'll work on commission only. It's ano lose situation. C.J. considers this. C.J. Wouldn't you make a lot more money in real estate?
It's not about the money. I've got plenty. I just want to do something I enjoy for a change.
Let's see if he can sell to Harvey. C.J. Great idea. If you can sell a boat to Harvey, you got the job.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Money in the bank. C.J. (calling to Kyle) Kyle. Come over here for a second.
Johnny approaches Harvey.
Hello, welcome to Mason Marine.
Thanks. Are you new?
I started today. How can I help you?

I want to take a trip to Mexico ina boat I bought for a hundred dollars, but the gas tank isn't big enough. I was thinking of constructing a raft and putting six 55-gallon drums on it and filling them with gas and running a fuel line from the raft to my motor. Do you think it would work?

That's very Macgyver of you. But, no, I don't think it will work. I do however have the perfect boat for you. Wait here. 21. 34 35 Johnny shows Harvey over to the deck and pulls out a chai for Harvey to sit in.
Harvey sits on the deck waiting. 36 Behind him, in the distance, Johnny pulls a beat up old D out of the dumpster. Johnny pushes the dingy on a wheelbarrow up to Harvey. boat is a real piece of crap.
We're having a sale on this boat. It's only a hundred dollars. This
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
A hundred dollars? For that?
How much would you pay for it?
I'll give you ten dollars for it. It actually would make a good planter for some of my cacti. Johnny pauses like he's really thinking about this offer.
No. I can't go that low. It won't take much to get this back on the water. I think I'll keep this one for myself. Johnny starts rolling the wheelbarrow away.
Okay, twenty-five.
Thirty-five and it's yours.
I'll take it.
Johnny, C.J., Frank, Steve, and Kyle watch as Harvey driv away with the dingy in the back of his truck. Johnny hands C.J. thirty-five dollars.
That doesn't count. That was in the dumpster.
Nobody said which boat.
Yeah, but -- C.J. You're hired. C.J. and Johnny shake hands. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23.

Johnny, Kyle, Steve, and Frank sit on the deck. A half em box of doughnuts sits on the table. Frank eats a maple lo Johnny reads a boating magazine. C.J. exits the shop pushing a dolly with a helium tank on C.J. Let's start blowing up some balloons and make this place look like we're having a party. Johnny gets up, followed by Kyle.
Aye aye, Captain.
I'll be right there. Let me just finish this cigarette.
Let me just hit the head real quick. Frank exits.
Johnny and Kyle stand blowing up balloons.
What is their deal? Are they here to sell or eat free doughnuts?
Yeah, they're a little lazy, but they know how to sell boats.
Are you kidding? Listen, Kyle, I'm about to sell more than the three of you combined. If you want to learn how to sell, you come talk to me.

Yeah, I appreciate that, but I'm only going to be here for a couple more weeks. My band is about to be signed. Frank exits carrying a big sign that says "SUPER GIGANTIC BLOWOUT SALE." (The word "SUPER" has been added to the ol sign.) He hangs the sign on the fence, crooked, and walks away. Johnny walks over to the sign and straightens it.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24.
Sales is all about the details.
Johnny and GARY look at a 22' Boston Whaler.
Do I hear a bit of an accent? Where are you from?
Asheville, North Carolina.
Really, I lived in Asheville. Right off Tunnel Road by Pete's Diner.
No kidding. I used to eat there all the time.
Yeah, Pete's a great guy. If you're back in Asheville, tell him I said hello.
I'll do that. Johnny passes the hull of the boat.
I hate to see it go, but if someone's going to buy it, I'd really like you to have it. This was my grandfather's Whaler. He taught me how to fish and chase women in this boat.
Really, then why are you selling it?
He just passed away and it's too emotional when I fish out of it now.
I'm really sorry about that.
Thanks. He took great care of this boat. You're not going to find one in better condition. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41 42 43 44 45 25.
The Whaler is hooked up to Gary's truck. Johnny pulls the chains connecting the trailer to the truck to make sure they're secure.
You're all set. Johnny waves and Gary drives away.
Frank stands beside a ski boat talking to a YOUNG CUSTOME
It's the Mercruiser 4.3 Liter. The way the Republicans have screwed up gas prices, your better off with this one than the 5.0. It's got plenty of pep and is a lot better on gas.

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE LOT 43

text: Kyle stands beside a low-profile, high performance boat.
This is a pussy-boat. You'll get so much play in this thing, your dick will fall off. The CAMERA PANS OVER to an 80-YEAR-OLD MAN wearing a flop white fishing hat.
Son, it fell off years ago. You got anything I can fish out of?
Steve stands beside a fishing boat talking to a man and h son, LARRY and LARRY JUNIOR. Steve is smoking a cigarette
My dad never took me fishing when I was a kid. Now I hate him... Just kidding... He's a great guy... When he's not drinking. So what do you think, cash or charge?
Johnny kneels down at the back of another truck. He pulls the safety chains, making sure they are tight.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

Okay, you're good to go. Enjoy yourself out on the water. The truck drives off towing the boat. Johnny walks back toward the building. The sun is setting C.J. stands in the doorway. Frank walks by. C.J. How'd it go with that customer?
Real good. He's got to check with his credit union and then he'll be back this weekend. C.J. Did you get his phone number?
Nope. Trust me, my customers call me back. C.J. Come on, Frank, you know better than that. Frank shrugs, goes into the building.
C.J. enters, talking on the phone. C.J. (into phone) Great, great, you're going to love this boat. I'll see you tomorrow. Madeline approaches C.J. as he hangs up the phone.
They accepted our offer on the house. C.J. pauses for a moment, unsure. C.J. Great, that's fantastic!
Is it?
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27.

Absolutely. Things are going great down at the shop. Johnny is just a phenomenal salesman. Tommy and Tyler enter. Tyler carries TUGGY the tug boat, old toy tug boat that was seen earlier in the picture of and his father. Tyler sets Tuggy on the table.
Tyler, take Tuggy off the table. Tyler sets Tuggy on the floor. C.J. (to the kids) We're moving to the new house!
Will I get my own room? C.J. Yes, you will.
Can I get a dog?
Only if it's a sled dog that can pull down an extra pay check. (to C.J.) We're going to need every dollar we can get to pay for this house.
Johnny stands beside a Ranger bass boat talking to a customer, MATT. Frank stands nearby.
Do you want the hundred and fifty horsepower motor for an extra five hundred or the ninety horsepower motor for the advertised price?
It doesn't come with this motor?
Not for that price. We'd lose our shirts if we did that. The ninety horsepower is a fine motor. It will get the job done, but this boat will scream with that hundred and fifty.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28.
Frank walks up.
The hundred and fifty horsepower motor comes standard with this boat.
Are you sure?
Positive.
Wow, my mistake. This boat is a hell of a deal. Thanks, Frank. Johnny turns back to Matt.
Sorry about that, Matt, but it's all the better deal for you. Since you're saving five hundred dollars, let's take a look at a bimini top and some accessories to really cherry it out.
Johnny enters carrying a stack of paperwork.

I got full bill on that Ranger and sold about a grand worth of accessories. C.J. That's great! You're doing a terrific job. I'd venture to say that you're almost as good a salesman as I am. Johnny smiles and turns to leave, but then turns back to
You and I should have a sell-off. You know, just for fun. C.J. I wouldn't want to embarrass you in front of the other guys.
Right, right. Well if you change your mind, let me know. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29.
Frank enters the bathroom. Johnny shoots in after him and pushes him up against the wall.
Listen Jimmy Buffett, if you ever cut in on one of my sales again, you'll be eating your doughnut through a straw. Johnny throws Frank to the side and walks away. Frank rub his sore neck.
Johnny waves to ANOTHER CUSTOMER, who drives away towing boat. Frank, Kyle, and Steve sit on the deck. Steve and Kyle sm
That guy can really sell, huh?
I could sell ten times as many boats as he does if I were willing to flush my integrity down the toilet.
Yeah, right. Johnny approaches them. C.J. walks out of the building. C.J. Great sales today.
Thanks, man. Hey, you guys want to go grab a beer?
No, thanks. My daughter has a soccer game.
I got band practice.
Can't, man. I got a little of this waiting for me. Steve pumps his hips as he stands up and starts moving aw
I met this fine honey online.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
50 C.J. I know it's none of my business, but you have a great wife at home. Is this girl really worth the risk?
Let me put it to you like this -- she's trying to set up a threesome with her mom.
Sweet!
